jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

B8FE8E43516641E381410F9E741D9C8C.description: Discuss the purpose of various dances in medieval times.

2F12BB6F91A44598AF596E48E305D640.description: Observe a variety of dances found in Alberta.

0FECA18AAF8E45B28E4A2630AE7FF855.description: Discuss examples of knowledge that First Nations, Metis, and Inuit can share through dance.

F29CFBBD9AB2419997E6F73BDBCFFA86.description: Demonstrate how artistic roles and responsibilities contribute to a sense of community

4FC1501A473B449DADC361BF87D1163D.description: Participate as a performer and an audience member in an artistic community.

796C54CC03744F609C347E60811B7BF5.description: Dances in the middle ages may have reflected religious beliefs.

8639D718DB614FF49CC6CC4C5A281E85.description: Culture was revealed through dances of the middle ages.

75D9CBDC8D644454A6F5C84389DFD76D.description: Dance in Alberta can reflect the culture of those who came before us and those who live here now

2CC6BC87751B468291F98C9327F1EC92.description: The culture of an artistic community is about shared ways of being together and reaching common goals.

363B6B3998984A2E9B4FF4F8947B1305.description: When communities unite through the arts, culture can be learned

CF9D8BF9281747E6820481E3B8906B91.description: Flamenco dance originated in India and was inspired to some extent by Arabic music and culture

E43AC012BA1D4060952C7898BCB37C58.description: The Silk Road provided a means for the spread of Islam to Spain and western Europe

8F20A52AC54B43C6AE6FE4860E6EDAA3.description: Muslim dances included the Whirling Dervish, which is characterized by fast movements and spinning

6EAC8CFCB92040529A10B46E03769C79.description: During medieval times, Muslim men and women were divided into two groups for dancing one for men and one for women

EAB50E8C258F4341BEAD52EF1F047A08.description:
Attitudes toward dance varied among different places within
medieval Muslim communities

E40887E1BC07423BBF53EB1A893BEF58.description: Non-religious (secular) dance was a part of court life in many medieval kingdoms and could include dances that were a form of entertainment at gatherings dances that were a source of fun and relaxation for participants dances of the noble courts, which included Basse/Saltarello

5F93E18AF8D8495FBE2A4A09011218C2.description: Religious (sacred) dances in medieval Europe were performed as part of rituals and ceremonies and can include liturgical dance as a form of movement used to pray and worship May dances performed on May 1 or during mid-summer celebrations Dance of Death, known as the Dance Macabre dance epidemics, such as the Tarantella, were performed with the belief that it could cure diseases

39C4EE74A0FE488FA128075458442A97.description: The Catholic Church in medieval Europe disapproved of certain kinds of dance, including pagan dances

23A22E1B3E14497A86381904E78C0749.description: Common dances performed in medieval Europe can include Midsummer Night's Eve dance the roundel, a slow dance performed in a circle the carole, a circle dance performed in mid-summer festivals the farandole, a lively dance where dancers form a chain by linking hands the cushion dance, where a dancer drops a cushion in front of a dance partner as an invitation to dance

5151BAD593CF4381AD8C2E1AB3F480AF.description: Pagan dances were performed in relation to rituals or ceremonies that celebrated gods

E6F811AB2CD84E2FBC838F424A078489.description: Dances in Alberta can reflect the history and traditions of communities and other areas of the world and can include French-Canadian dances Ukrainian dance Irish dance

3581AB4B01664FAF9E8F74DF53FA35CC.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit dances can reflect the history and traditions of communities that are indigenous to Alberta, and can include Metis jigging  square dance First Nations  round dance  powwow dances

77A0EC45E4314895A001545A22D7F6D8.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit dance is holistic in nature and can have individual and collective benefits, including social well-being physical health spiritual connection emotional and mental well-being intellectual development

ECAFB61D00ED41C5860C60E5B99E3F32.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit dance can represent cultural stories and traditions show gratitude and reverence demonstrate reciprocity mimic elements of the natural world, including animals and water reflect spirituality contribute to healing

9C27CED0667C4E9FADE63EA3D5B38E6C.description: Perspectives can be developed by experiencing the dances of other individuals, including folk dance and social dance

A05254E424814F37A6FA86F170A79098.description: The culture of an artistic community can support the caring and respectful inclusion of all participants

D445D731863F414D9945656884E6AA27.description: Vocabulary related to dance can be used to objectively describe movement

A7D8D34317CC4358B45E4230EC6290ED.description: Culture can be enhanced when members of a dance community participate, communicate, engage, and share responsibilities.

54F3D2DA59584204BD9225DE4EA70609.description: Students relate how culture is reflected in dance across various times and places

72600118618E4E4796D012A405500234.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate.

B6E3D769050242B1ACEF139C546C01C4.description: Respond to various auditory, visual, or physical cues when dancing

6D0183CB31814AA8967177B6FDB6E53A.description: Discuss solutions to movement problems encountered when representing a narrative in dance

888E93B1D8DF45FFAD358EBDD398C26B.description: Make artistic choices when exploring how to represent narrative in dance

0E8A11611D9D469884C2B9D514A85510.description: Collaborate with others when generating and representing a narrative through dance

B95351542CDE4E98B2DB92AA64562D08.description: Share and replicate movement ideas with others.

CADD9B281BDC4E59874A4B2B071EE54E.description: Create movement patterns that reflect a point of view or perspective.

905D03C2733B4258AB6D2DCD685C0F89.description: Create movement patterns or phrases that can illustrate a part of a narrative

66A7B8B231534E3784C0DECD8C055EE0.description: Construct a narrative based on an inspiration

8AF0D0F95BCD4D20A1FCE7CA5A1B42EC.description: Experiment with various ways to structure a narrative in dance

AC40845F0183411AA68DFCF7EDFDDA38.description: A narrative in dance can be shaped by the dancer or ensemble.

54C2AC42EEA24DF78485188C608AC7A8.description: The way in which the elements of dance are applied to movement can convey ideas, feelings, and perspectives.

63FAC54CCCA44A01833B8B22724644FB.description: A narrative can communicate points of view or perspectives of an individual or group

7849883A63F3495A88564B6E5912A7BC.description: A narrative can be factual or fictitious.

1DEDDB6A945C49298C9C3FB145E95B76.description: A narrative in dance can be illustrated as a partial or whole representation

BF16055CD72945F8A589797E20AAB8F4.description: Expression of a narrative in dance can be refined by applying creative processes

6CDF4477F8E94B2CA55F35620568136B.description: Physical cues can be given in dance through focus, facial expressions, and contact with other dancers

2FBEBB8494944203B26038E6936FBB56.description: Visual cues can include the use of formations, pathways, and directions

F50FD2A6228B487FBF157DDD5C754053.description: Auditory cues can be given by the teacher or choreographer and can include movement directions feedback in the moment counting beats aloud directing when to start or stop a movement or dance

BBFB38F8F6294EC4BCB1EA603D0776C0.description: Auditory, physical, or visual cues can direct when movements for a narrative begin or end.

005A0024EFEB45E38720A5E620C3E1A0.description: Narrative in dance can be enhanced by demonstrating the relationship between a dancer and the movement of others, including meeting and parting a dancer and the music a dancer and an object

E062C8CB571747AE96B1B65E1BE6119D.description: A dancer and ensemble can shape a narrative through their movements, reactions, thoughts, and ideas

104495DD063B4D6A8F363383FFEA2CB8.description: Facial expressions, body posture, and movement can contribute to how a narrative is expressed in dance

4F617EDC74D648B983B20F2A5AB59C65.description: Force can intensify, elaborate, or highlight the way that movements communicate perspectives, ideas, or feelings

7FF050ED56AA487D86F9F58CDDF02099.description: Points of view or perspectives can reflect ideas or knowledge feelings experiences culture beliefs

D5A125F0041B4B7DB0B871D24C82A857.description: Inspiration for a narrative may come from a variety of sources.

6F4DE28393C046FE92D08A1E7BB14678.description: Choreographic forms can give structure to a narrative, including AB (binary form) ABA (ternary form) ABC (suite), which has three contrasting sections narrative that follows a storyline

E02C7F2A7AB34A648704189F230649EB.description: A narrative can be structured using various dance styles, which can include ballet creative dance folk and social dance

C8DFE13136634C4AA98B6403E0DDC7B3.description: The elements of dance can be used to structure a narrative through movement patterns or phrases an entire dance stillness, including tableau, where bodies create shapes to create an image

088F8B7D8424474DB5210CE4534EE77F.description: A narrative in dance may or may not represent a sequence of events in the order in which they happened.

C01FFCDE3C50464A8AE82D6D725D91E3.description: Students use narrative as a structure for organizing movements in dance

110331A4AFC249BF9B8D5350A50E1CA0.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge

C1DD7D63DCE2411EA9D7354FE1B1E3A7.description: Participate in regular warm-ups and cool-downs in dance

3694451686FA467AAA46427649F08D75.description: Recognize the role of muscle contraction in executing certain movements

832DB8515DE9450B8ED7C6D59A398DF4.description: Experience various dance styles that use sustained and percussive flows of energy

5F72ACA391A34722B3F94E633F7518DA.description: Describe how force can be used to highlight a movement

1D2A6FC69D1B471EBD82DEE7F1FBD7C0.description: Explore how to isolate force to specific body parts.

0117A7F0BF4B4161874696BBF30C8468.description: Experiment with bound-flow and free-flow movements.

6F2A322DFAB84E71A17242623ED01A8C.description: Identify the amount of force the body requires for certain movements.

84DFCA19EA614799B5F0CF3854CF4FBB.description: Use dance vocabulary to describe the quality of a movement when force is applied.

EA5E805E59C84642BA1909C96ED9C506.description: Explore movements that require passive or active weight

0C7453B9A6FB45B788B88714AEF938AC.description: Combine weight, energy, and speed in the exploration of movement possibilities

B606F627A0314FB99A006458FB984130.description: Observe how force can be used to support the weight of others.

717FA643EAD647CEB05B38BD97881473.description: Sustain a steady beat when executing movement patterns

028ECFA4CB6C42C29A7BEDECF7C712EF.description: Recognize the timing required to successfully execute movements in unison or sequentially.

0B751286EA274A6A8AFF577D7A187437.description: Identify how accents can be illustrated using movement

BDC39FE3331B413183BBF238BA946E29.description: Experience how changes in tempo, metre, or accent may influence the duration of a movement

474EF6035AAC4A15AABD7ED13E9697F3.description: Observe a variety of styles and genres of dance to experience how a dancer moves in relation to tempo, metre, accent, or rhythm

1456168EE7124331A3A10648731391A0.description: Explore various stimuli as a means to direct movement

93FD99E1416B4E139C5E22471B9EE883.description: Apply movements to the rhythm of music or spoken texts

5AB3ADAC035640BABC50CDCC27BFD06E.description: Identify how the duration of a movement can be influenced by force or speed

59237666EAE740B3823372B1EA2B86A6.description: Discuss how the duration of a movement can create meaning

4016C1E0C18C45F58B692157F4525D30.description: Combine movement phrases or patterns of varying durations to form a movement sequence

AB4B64FFB73D4071A6EB7210E0CFC352.description: Demonstrate how to begin and end a movement pattern or phrase within an allotted time

78F7B6CFD20D4B0FAFBF7B8AB1262F5C.description: Force is not visible, but its effects can be observed through movement

43E5970A1A2D48DC9D8DBA9DEAD38CC0.description: Force is the push-pull relationship between a dancer and gravity

F38F1DA5A6EF40519F85BF635C80A2DC.description: Time can determine how a dancer moves in relation to a tempo, a metre, an accent, or a rhythm

657650090BA84D67822DB237003074C7.description: Time is the duration of a movement or dance

1E08D6DCAF9D4CF098ADADAF31FDF5E6.description: Sustained flow is seen in movements that are slow, smooth, continuous, and even

165A56B8F05D4AB4A435505AEF3F537E.description: Percussive flow is seen in movements that have sharp, sudden, and short bursts of energy

5BED171442354FE8AABD82E6D0B8EF2A.description: Force is used in movement through sustained and percussive flow

4AF01B55EF8140DEA095516C3E10F93D.description: When applied to movement, force can highlight or reinforce parts of a movement, pattern, or phrase

7AFFE62DDB0F44DDB493E1B4F62C5085.description: Warm-ups and cool-downs assist in preparing the body for dance

34685C30572A4C29B64147865C0E6A4B.description: The contraction of muscles is required to execute movement and maintain balance in dance

1560E5B410D540368D1188B728E729EF.description: Force is felt in the muscles and is engaged by contracting the muscles.

9EF5BBD756A844BAA5B4123AAD30AD7B.description: Force, as an element of dance, can create flow movements described as bound-flow movements, which are rigid and can be stopped easily free-flow movements, which are fluid and not easily stopped

52466CAB97564937B12B492B1BD7463E.description: Force requires muscle strength to execute certain movements or to support the weight of another dancer

FDC6DD84C3F6468999C1DF61876A0A04.description: Varying the weight and speed of movements creates various movement energies, including sharp smooth swingy, involving a drop into gravity, including swing, sway, or rock shaky, which creates force through vibratory movements, including wiggle, vibrate, or bounce

2AA5DF1EEBC249D99C4930E29C99B87B.description: Weight can be described as passive or heavy, when the body gives into gravity active and energetic movement against gravity

004DAA0FE1E44329959A13D95BC57250.description: Energy of movements, including smooth, swingy, shaky, and sharp qualities, can be executed with weight and speed.

9FEF76F65B0B41AB90656B0D9EC48552.description: Force influences the quality of a movement when energy, weight, and flow of movement are applied

545D481FC14C418F8FCBA4A64749A5CA.description: Movement and timing can vary across styles of dance, including jazz ballet hip hop social dance folk dance

B14DA87479814C0FAC5504B2EF9766B3.description: Dance steps may have specific movements and timing, as seen in the basic triple step, including waltz  has a slow-quick-quick step pattern polka  has a quick-quick-slow step pattern schottische  three steps and a hop

79AFE3D273EC48D693D2A44C515BC73D.description: Timing refers to moving to the beat of the music and moving in relation to other dancers, including before or after one another in unison

A79CCE741A7F4A1C97C595E3935A5F09.description: Auditory stimuli can influence how a dancer moves, including music spoken text instrument sounds vocal sounds

85AABE2C02D843229CDEC42E6DC77531.description: The duration of a dance usually has a relationship to the duration of auditory stimuli that accompany it.

574A6461FD9F4706A388E33439F39549.description: Duration of a movement can create meaning in dance.

A3D1FC3D5CBE4B9990DF008152D8E2B3.description: The speed of a movement can be performed quickly for a short time slowly for a long time to gradually get faster to gradually get slower

50695038D130492BA64CA2F0A381632C.description: Duration of a movement, phrase, pattern, or dance, can be short, long, or medium and include pauses and stillness.

303FC249F63D401BBE6AD2DE7B8C76A6.description: Duration of a movement can change when force or speed is applied

5B14DE1EBAA04BB9B02FBFAFC73A06B1.description: Time can determine when a movement begins or ends

99E120DDC7EA4622AF6FE4277AA4889A.description: Students analyze time and force in relation to the elements of dance

74A66C6D8C4F4EA3A9566A47B572D0A0.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
